job_title: After School Program Director in New York, NY
pros: The position does allow for one to be somewhat independent and make decisions that affect the day to day operations of the after school program. You are entrusted with many responsibilities, which can be a great thing. You can gain a lot of experience working with so many people, from management, to school administration, to program funders, to students, etc.
cons:
The company seems to set their employees up for failure. To make a long story short, I was thrown into the fire without proper preparation and training. From the top down, the company is very disorganized and not very supportive. It seems that the different departments (HR, Education, etc.) are rarely on the same page. The salary is decent, until you take into account the amount of time one actually puts in, and the amount of stress the company creates. 

During my one week of training, one of the senior management officials told us that if we leave work at 6 everyday, then we are probably not doing a good job. Keep in mind that in our handbooks that our required hours of work are from 10am to 6pm.

pros:
They have a ton of programs throughout the city so there are plenty of opportunities to make a difference in the lives of kids who really need it. 

You can advance in the organization relatively quickly but that's due to the high rate of turnover.

Good opportunities for part-time employees, sports coaches and teaching artists.  There is a lot of flexibility to do your own thing because the organization doesn't have a focus.
cons:
The organizational culture is terrible.  Absolutely terrible.  It is a very difficult place to work if you are in the main office. 

Turnover is extremely high and the workload of site-based staff is not respected.  Things are often sprung on program staff at the last minute.  There is way too much bureaucracy and self-importance that prevents work from actually being done to improve programs. There are a lot of duplicate positions and titles.  

The organization lacks focus and does everything mediocre as opposed to excelling at a few things.

With such high turnover, there is no consistency in anything, from human resources, to programming, to employee evaluations and supervision, to event quality, to accounting, etc.   

The nature of the work of youth development is stressful enough yet this company adds to that stress.

If you are looking for full-time work and believe in the mission, there are other organizations out there that may be better options.

job_title: Assistant Site Manager in New York, NY
pros: The hourly rate, but don't for a minute think you'll actually be making that much $$.
cons:
Where do I begin?
LOTS of unpaid work, on your own time, writing lesson plans if you're an activity specialist, entering attendance for each period and making schedules if you're a data specialist. If you're both, figure you'll make half of your hourly or less.
NOT ENOUGH STAFF for the number of kids.
The "Trip Training" is a joke. While I was there, 2 kids were left behind on trips from different schools. Police had to be called to find one of them. All were eventually safe and sound but supervisors AND TRAINERS who should have lost their jobs did not.
Summer session training is worse than a joke. DO NOT EAT THE LUNCH PROVIDED-- you will get food poisoning as many attendees did the summer I went.
The main office staff is rude and unhelpful and think they rule the world. They absorb a lot of program money by buying themselves catered lunches. Take a look at the food expense on SASF's IRS-990 form to see what I mean.
SASF execs clearly have friends in city govt or this organization couldn't survive. It is corrupt and rotten.

To anyone who wants to be a role model or a mentor to the students in city public schools, this is the job for you.
